response.answer_text: Is this a new condition for an old phone? If so, you may need a new battery. Typical smartphone batteries last 1–3 years depending on your use. There are some good answers here, so I’m not going to repeat everything. Let’s take a look at what eats a phone’s power the fastest, and see if you can at least understand what’s going on. First is your cellular modem. A typical phone can transmit at very low power, or it can transmit at 350mW or more. When your phone transmits, the cell tower analyzes the power it’s receiving (dubbed Receive Signal Strength Indication, or RSSI) and instructs your phone to increase or decrease transmit power, depending on how it’s being heard. You have no control over this. If your signal strength is weak, 1 bar or less, you might see your battery dying before lunchtime in a typical day. At full power, you might well have a 75% charge by the end of the work day. It’s that important. What can you do about it? Not much. Turn off cellular and just use WiFi, if its available. Change carriers. Bring a big USB battery or get a wall plug and keep your phone charged. Next one is your screen. After the celluar radio, the screen can be the biggest power hog. To save power, dial down the brightness, or at least set it in auto-bright mode. And finally, what do you do with the phone? If you’re playing games, that’s going to eat phone battery. That runs the CPU faster than normal, kicks in all some or all of the high-performance cores in your multi-core CPU, and turns on the GPU. There’s nothing you can do to reduce high power use of your phone other than to not run the higher power applications, or only do that when plugged in.  Use the battery meter (or whatever the equivalent of this is in your OS, if you’re in the 20% of the world that isn’t using Android) and see how your phone’s power is being used. This will help you find out where the power is going, and at least understand what you need to change to save battery power. But you still may need that charger or extra battery. If your cellular signal isn’t strong where you use the phone, the phone will die fast.

I can only suggest the standard stuff… Re-boot and upate… always a good move before attempting to resolve any problem.Disable any apps that you don’t need.Stop the services that you don’t need all the time, BlueTooth and GPS for example.Reduce screen brightness.Turn off ‘vibrate’, it uses more power than audio notification.Connect to WiFi as much as possible, but it there is little WiFi and it is weak, turn it right off. Depending on how old the device is you might want to see about having the battery checked to see if it needs replacing. Most batteries only have a 3–500 cycle count before they start to need replacing. That is about 2–3 years of normal usage, about a full charge or less every night. If you are draining a fully charged battery and then recharging to full and draining it again then you are using two cycles in that one day. Therefor shortening your cycle count before it needs replacing. A simple thing to go by with smartphones is to limit background activities. Not having social media apps on your device is one way, limiting their use and not allowing them to run in the background is another. If you are gaming on your phone then plug it in when you're gaming. The battery is a replenishable item just like the tires on your car. How you use it will depend on its lifespan. You can also turn down the brightness, the display is one of the biggest power draws of you smartphone. If you have the brightness at full on a 4K screen at 120mHz refresh playing Fortnight then no wonder the battery is draining fast.

Replace the battery is the only way. Once the cycle limit for the battery is reached, battery is over heated while charging or pretty much anything to do with the battery no longer having full capacity can not be fixed by any method. Lipo/LiFe batteries have a useful life span, once that cycle limit is reached they degrade very quickly. Once this happens it it irreversible. Charging while too cold/too hot can also impact the lifespan before they start to degrade, sometimes it wont happen instantly, it can impact the cycle limit. Short charging is bad for you battery. By this I mean charging when battery percentage is above 20–30%. Or “top up" charging where you top you battery up a little, not complete a full charge cycle will impact the amount of full charge cycles before degradation sets in. Sorry to say, its time for a new battery or phone

That means they have vented losing precious moisture. As soon as that moisture is gone they will no longer take a charge at all. This goes for all batteries; lithium, Nicad, even lead acid if you fast charge them and the charge controller is bad they will vent water and electrolyte if left on past a complete charge. I question if the charge controller is bad. Have the phone serviced and give them a description in writing of the problem specifically ask them to replace the battery and check the charge controller.
